coredata.dc:title: Investigation of Cu heteroatoms and Cu clusters in Fe-Cu alloy and their special effect mechanisms on the Fenton-like catalytic activity and reusability
coredata.dc:creator: Xia, Qixing
Zhang, Dongjie
Yao, Zhongping
Jiang, Zhaohua
coredata.dc:description: Fe/Cu bimetallic materials are promising Fenton-like catalysts to deal with the increasing environmental pollution. However, it remains a great challenge to prepare conveniently desirable Fe/Cu co-catalysts with brilliant catalytic efficiency and simultaneously reveal their co-catalytic mechanism. Herein, we report a facile approach of generating Fe-Cu alloys with outstanding Fenton-like catalytic performance via a straightforward electrodeposition method. The degradation ability of Fe-Cu alloy mainly comes from Fe2+/H2O2 reaction, while the Cu components including the Cu heteroatoms in Fe lattice and the independent Cu clusters in alloy play a notable assistant role. Experiments and density functional theory (DFT) calculations indicate that the Cu heteroatoms enhance the capacity of adjacent Fe atoms for the adsorption of H2O2 to generate more •OH, while the independent Cu clusters suppress the surface passivation of catalyst for improving the reusability in cycle experiments. Our study will promote the industrial application of bimetallic Fenton-like catalysts for water treatment.

Independent Cu clusters
Fenton-like process
Reusability

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: (a) Illustration for the synthesis procedure of Fe-Cu alloy, and (b) the composition change variations as Cu/Fe ratios.

The phenol degradation (a), kinetic curves (b) and the kinetic constants (c) in Fenton-like systems with various catalysts (other conditions: 0.10 g/L catalyst, 35 ppm phenol, 6 mmol/L H2O2, pH 4.0), and the effects of H2O2 dosage (d) and cycle number (e) on the Fenton-like process via ZVI, Fe-10Cu and Fe-25Cu.
XRD patterns of ZVI, Fe-5Cu, Fe-10Cu, Fe-25Cu, Fe-50Cu, Fe-75Cu and 100Cu at the ranges of 2θ = 38°~ 87° (a) and 2θ = 41.5–46.5° (b1 and b2).
The SEM images of samples with the different ratios of Fe/Cu from 1 ~ 0: (a, a′) ZVI, (b, b′) Fe-10Cu, (c, c′) Fe-25Cu, (d, d′) Fe-50Cu, (e, e′) Fe-75Cu, (f, f′) 100Cu.

(a) Fe K-edge XANES results of ZVI, Fe-10Cu, Fe-25Cu and Fe foil; (b) Cu K-edge XANES and (c) EXAFS results of 100Cu, Fe-10Cu, Fe-25Cu and Cu foil; TEM (d) and HRTEM (e) images of Fe-25Cu, and the FFT results (e1 and e2) of different positions at HRTEM images.
Fe2p XPS spectra of fresh (a) and used (b) ZVI, Fe-10Cu, Fe-25Cu, and Cu2p XPS spectra of fresh (c) and used (d) Fe-10Cu, Fe-25Cu.

The phenol degradation efficiency of Fe-25Cu/H2O2 system for different cycle number at 60 min (a), the XRD patterns of fresh Fe-25Cu and used Fe-25Cu after Run 10 (b), and the SEM morphology and element composition of used Fe-25Cu after Run 10 (c).

The EPR spectra of Fenton-like systems via ZVI and Fe-25Cu at 1 min and 10 min (a) and optimized configurations for H2O2 adsorption on the Fe atoms at the normal Fe lattice (a) and the Cu doped Fe lattice (b): Violet – Fe atom, reddish-Cu atom, white-H atom, red-O atom.
The C1s XPS results of used ZVI (a), Fe-10Cu (b) and Fe-25Cu (c).

Schematic diagrams of enhanced Fenton-like process via Fe-25Cu/H2O2 system (a) the Cu species accelerating the transform of Fe2+/Fe3+; (b) the independent Cu clusters suppressing the formation of passivation layer on Fe-25Cu surface.

head.ce:title: Investigation of Cu heteroatoms and Cu clusters in Fe-Cu alloy and their special effect mechanisms on the Fenton-like catalytic activity and reusability

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Fe/Cu bimetallic materials are promising Fenton-like catalysts to deal with the increasing environmental pollution. However, it remains a great challenge to prepare conveniently desirable Fe/Cu co-catalysts with brilliant catalytic efficiency and simultaneously reveal their co-catalytic mechanism. Herein, we report a facile approach of generating Fe-Cu alloys with outstanding Fenton-like catalytic performance via a straightforward electrodeposition method. The degradation ability of Fe-Cu alloy mainly comes from Fe2+/H2O2 reaction, while the Cu components including the Cu heteroatoms in Fe lattice and the independent Cu clusters in alloy play a notable assistant role. Experiments and density functional theory (DFT) calculations indicate that the Cu heteroatoms enhance the capacity of adjacent Fe atoms for the adsorption of H2O2 to generate more •OH, while the independent Cu clusters suppress the surface passivation of catalyst for improving the reusability in cycle experiments. Our study will promote the industrial application of bimetallic Fenton-like catalysts for water treatment.

ce:section.ce:para:
Nowadays, an increasing number of toxic contaminations have been brought in water, which cause serious environmental and health problems [1–3]. Fenton-like catalysts such as Fe-based materials can active H2O2 into •OH with high oxidation potential (+2.8 V), which can mineralize most of organic pollutants (Eq. 1). Among Fenton-like catalysts, zero valence iron (ZVI) [4,5] with low price, earth abundance, relatively good activity and magnetic controllability, which makes it more practical in the industry application. However, the unsatisfied activity and reusability of ZVI are still a challenge due to its surface passivation [6,7]. In order to gain better catalytic performance, several field-assisted techniques such as electricity [8,9], photo [10] and ultrasound [11,12] have been developed to couple with the Fenton-like process of ZVI, but they also make the degradation of contaminations more complex and expensive. Hence, the strategies for modifying materials themselves are more meaningful to improve the catalytic activity of ZVI and ZVI-based catalysts [13–15].
(1) Fe2+ + H2O2 + H+ → Fe3+ + •OH + H2O

Cu and its oxides, which can also activate H2O2 into hydroxyl radicals [16,17], are always employed to cooperated with Fe-based materials for design Fenton-like co-catalytic materials [18,19]. Several Fe°/Cu° co-catalyst were developed by simple chemical reduction methods [15,20], but the surface areas for Fenton-like oxidation were relatively small due to their single spherical structure. In order to improve the reactive area, the majority of reported technologies of Fe/Cu co-catalysts always take the strategy to construct Fe and Cu species on the supports with large specific surface area, such as mesoporous materials and caron composites [20–23], but their complex procedures caused low-yield and high-cost, which are not suitable for large-scale application. In addition, most studies hold the view that the superior activity of Fe/Cu bimetallic catalysts was mainly contributed to the cooperation of Cu+/Cu2+ cycle and of Fe3+/Fe2+ cycles [15,24–26]. However, besides the phase composition, the practical performance of catalysts is closely associated with their precise structure, and the development of Fenton-like catalyst have been increasingly focused on the atomic level and the nano level [27,28]. With the purpose of providing a guidance to design desirable catalysts, it is essential to further explore the co-catalytic mechanism of Fe/Cu bimetallic materials as clearly as possible, especially figuring out the effect differences of various components based on their precise existence states.

In this work, we prepared a novel Fe-Cu bimetallic catalyst with micro/nano multi-dimensional structure by a facile, cost-effective and easy-controllable electrodeposition method, as like Fig. 1(a). Different from commercial Fe-Cu particles and previous FeCu catalysts in refs. [15,24], the as-prepared catalysts possess larger specific surface area for providing more Fenton-like active sites, as presented in Table S1. The phase composition of alloys was investigated detailly as the ratios of Cu/Fe increased, like Fig. 1(b). With the help of structural characterization tools and DFT calculation, we could figure out the existence states of Fe/Cu in catalysts and clarify the catalytic roles of Fe and Cu, as well as the possible catalytic mechanism of degradation reactions. This reported Fe/Cu catalysts have potential application prospect and provide a new sight for reasonably designing active and reusable Fenton-like catalysts in the field of water purification.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Preparation of micro-nano structure Fe-Cu alloy
ce:section.ce:para: The multi-dimensional micro-nano structure Fe-Cu alloys were prepared by electrodeposition. Briefly, the electrolyte was composed of 0.5 mol/L FeSO4+CuSO4 and 50 mL/L anhydrous ethanol. The electro-deposition conditions were 1.6 A/dm2 of current density, 25 ℃ of solution temperature, and 20 s of electrodeposited time. A pure copper bar with the length of 10 cm and the diameter of 0.6 mm was utilized as the cathode, and a ring-shaped graphite was the anode. After electrodeposition process, the obtained product was shaken off from the cathode and collected in a centrifuge tube, and then washed by deionized water and anhydrous ethanol for 3 times, respectively. Subsequently, the product was dried in a vacuum under 60 ℃. Corresponding to the ratio of Fe2+ and Cu2+ in electrolyte, the obtained samples were labeled as Fe-xCu (x is the percentage of Cu2+), as labeled in Table S2. Among them, the products prepared from single FeSO4 solution or CuSO4 solution were numbered as ZVI and 100Cu.

X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the samples were detected by a Rigaku D/max-γB diffractometer with Cu Kα (λ = 0.15406 nm) radiation. The morphology of the sample and element distributions were characterized with field-emission scanning electron microscope (SEM, NanoLab 600i, America) and high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM, FEI Tecnai G2 F30, America). Surface composition of the sample was analyzed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) equipped with PHI 5400 ESCA System with Al Kα radiation at 1486.6 eV. Nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms determined at 77 K using a 3H-2000PS1 surface analyzer was employed to test the BET surface areas (S BET) of samples, and the sample was outgassed under vacuum at 473 K before test. The X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) spectra of the Fe K-edge and Cu K-edge of samples were measured in fluorescence mode at beamline 1W1B station (Beijing Synchrotron Radiation Facility). The electron beam energy was 3.5 GeV, and the maximum stored current was 260 mA.

The catalytic activity of Fe-Cu alloy was evaluated by phenol Degradation experiments. The batch reactor with 50 mL of 35 mg/L phenol and 0.1 g/L catalyst was stirred at 20 ℃, and the pH value of phenol solution was adjusted to pH 4.0 by dilute sulfuric acid. Once H2O2 was added in the reactor, the Fenton-like process for phenol removal was activated. At the given processing time interval, 0.5 mL solution without catalyst was collected by using a 0.22 µm Nafion membrane for measuring the concentration of phenol and metal ions leaching. Specifically, the phenol concentration was measured with 4-aminoantipyrine at 510 nm on a UV/Vis spectrophotometer (Lambda XLS, PerkinElmer, America), and the metal ions leaching were measured by ICP-MS (Icap7600, ICP-OES, Britain). The electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) signals of Fenton-like systems were detected by EPR spectrometer (EMSplus10/12, Bruker, Germany) with using 5,5-dimethyl-1-pyrrolin-N-oxide (DMPO) as radical spin-trapper.

First-principles DFT calculations were performed by using the Vienna ab initio Simulation Package (VASP) in our work [29] . The projector-augmented wave (PAW) potentials were used to describe the electron-ion interactions and the electron exchange-correction function was described by the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) parametrized by Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) [30]. The cutoff energy was set to 500 eV. The initial crystal structures were taken from literature [31], and the atomic positions were fully optimized until the forces on the atoms are below 0.05 eV/Å The convergence threshold for self-consistent-field (SCF) iteration was set at 10−6 eV. The adsorption energy was calculated as A.E. = E adsorbate/surface – E substrate – E molecule, where E adsorbate/surface, E substrate and E molecule denoted the total energy of substrate with adsorbate, substrate, and free molecule, respectively.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Fenton-like activity and reusability of Fe-Cu alloy
ce:section.ce:para: The catalytic capability of Fenton-like systems via ZVI, Fe-5Cu, Fe-10Cu, Fe-25Cu, Fe-50Cu, Fe-75Cu and 100Cu was evaluated by phenol degradation experiments, as shown in Fig. 2. The degradation curves (Fig. 2a) clearly indicate that the catalytic activity of Fe-Cu increases firstly and then decreases with the improvement of Cu content, and Fe-10Cu has the best performance and could remove phenol more than 90% within 5 min. ZVI possesses almost the same catalytic activity to Fe-25Cu, and the degradation efficiencies of phenol by the corresponding Fenton-like systems could reach 90% within 15 min. However, the activity of Fe-50Cu, Fe-75Cu and 100Cu is relatively terrible, and the degradation efficiencies of phenol by their Fenton-like systems within 15 min are only about 17%, 16% and 8%, respectively. This signifies that the suitable Cu content in Fe-Cu alloys could promote Fenton-like degradations, but too more Cu content is against the activity.

In addition, the phenol adsorption result of various catalysts (Fig. S1) indicates that the adsorption amounts of phenol are only 3~7%, and there is no obvious difference in adsorption behaviors, which disclose that the Cu content mainly impact the degradation behaviors of Fe-Cu alloys, especially the degradation kinetic curves in Fig. 2(b) and (c). Based on the kinetic curves’ slopes in each Fenton-like system, the degradation processes are divided into two stages, and the corresponding kinetic constants are displayed in Fig. 2(c). The orders of kinetic constants at stage 1 are Fe-10Cu > Fe-5Cu > Fe-25Cu ≈ ZVI, similar to the phenol degradation results. However, the orders of kinetic constants at stage 2 are Fe-25Cu > Fe-10Cu > Fe-5Cu > ZVI, which happen to match the Cu amount in Fe-Cu alloy. This suggests that the effect mechanisms of Cu content in different stages is diverse, which might be closely related to the specific Cu components in Fe-Cu alloys.

We analyzed the influence of H2O2 dosage on the degradation behaviors of ZVI, Fe-10Cu and Fe-25Cu, as presented in Fig. 2(d). Fig. 2(d) reveals that the catalytic activity of ZVI declines remarkably when H2O2 dosage increases, which results from two surface-passivation influences of excessive H2O2 dosage [32,33]: one is that H2O2 can react with •OH into •O2H (Eq. 2), decreasing the oxidation potential of dominant radicals from + 2.8 V (•OH) to + 0.8 V (•O2H); the other one is that the Fe species are oxidized overly by much more H2O2, and so effective Fe species (Fe2+) could not be re-generated for the sustaining Fenton-oxidation of phenol (Eq. 3). On the contrary, the increase of H2O2 dosage has fewer negative effects on the degradation processes via Fe-10Cu and Fe-25Cu, exhibiting more significant stability than ZVI, which might be result from that the Cu components could timely reduce the valence of Fe species (Eq. 4) to overcome the strong oxidation-passivation of H2O2. Due to the reaction of excessive H2O2 and •OH, a small drop of catalytic activity of Fe-Cu is observed.
(2) H2O2 + •OH → •O2H + H2O
(3) 2Fe2+ + 2 H+ + H2O2 → 2Fe3+ + 3 H2O
(4) Fe3+ + 1/2Cu° → Fe2+ + 1/2Cu2+

Desirable reusability is one of most important properties of catalyst for industrial application. Fig. 2(e) displays the effect of cycle number on the catalytic activity of ZVI, Fe-10Cu and Fe-25Cu. After each Run, the samples were collected by magnet and only washed by deionized water without any further treatment before the next run. It suggests that the catalytic activity of ZVI decreased significantly over cycles, and the degradation efficiency of phenol at Run 3 for 40 min was only 44%, much below that at Run 1 (99%). on the contrary, the reusability of Fe-Cu alloy was far better than ZVI. Especially, Fe-25Cu possesses a stable reactivity that could remove > 98% phenol within 40 min, presenting the optiaml reaubility in this wrok. Besides, the reusability of Fe-10Cu is inferior to Fe-25Cu, indicating the reusability of Fe-Cu alloys is correlated to their components, which would be further discussed at Section 3.2 with the structural characterization results of Fe-Cu alloys. From the degradation behaviors, it could be obtaiend that ZVI are easily surface-passivated due to over oxidation of Fe species or the deposition of contamination [24,34–36], while Fe-Cu alloys still keep the desirable activity to generated •OH by reacting with higher-concentration H2O2 or effectively remove organic pollutants in cycle experiments, which exhibit a promising potential for practical applications.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Structure and composition of Fe-Cu alloy
ce:section.ce:para: Fig. 3 displays the phase compositions and micro-morphologies of hierarchical Fe-Cu alloys with various Fe/Cu ratios. From the XRD results (Fig. 3a and b), it can be obtained that ZVI is composed of α-Fe (ICPDS: 87-0722) with body-centered cubic lattice (bcc), and the 100Cu sample is metallic copper (ICPDS: 70-3039) with face-centered cubic lattice (fcc). As for the Fe-Cu alloys, the main composition of Fe-5Cu, Fe-10Cu and Fe-25Cu is Fe phase, but the strongest diffraction peak of Fe (110) has a negative shift, caused by Cu heteroatoms doping into the Fe lattice. Meanwhile, there is a tiny peak related to Cu (111) observed in the XRD pattern of Fe-25Cu, meaning that the Cu atoms could be deposited as independent clusters when the Cu amount goes up to a certain extent. On the contrary, the main composition of Fe-50Cu and Fe-75Cu is Cu phase, because of the strongest peak corresponding to Cu (111) appears on the XRD results. However, unlike the peak of Fe (110) shifting left in Fig. 3b1, the peak of Cu (111) remains stable in Fig. 3b2, but their intensities increase with the Fe/Cu ratios decreasing, which imply that Fe heteroatoms might affect the crystallization degree of Cu phase.

On account of their similar atomic radius, Fe and Cu atoms are likely to enter mutual crystals and form solid solutions. That is to say, the main crystalline phase in Fe-Cu alloys is Fe phase with Cu heteroatoms (when Cu2+ content is lower than 25%) or Cu phase with Fe heteroatoms (when Cu2+ content is more than 50%). Owing to the radius size of Fe atom (0.126 nm) smaller than Cu atom (0.145 nm), the interplanar spacing of Fe (110) becomes larger when larger Cu heteroatoms enter the crystal lattice of Fe phase, while the interplanar spacing of Cu (111) changes little when smaller Fe atoms enter Cu phases. Overall, with the increase of Cu/Fe ratios, the phase compositions of Fe-Cu alloys are Fe phase (Fe-5Cu, Fe-10Cu), Fe phase + Cu clusters (Fe-25Cu) and Cu phase (Fe-50Cu, Fe-75Cu), respectively.

Fig. 4 shows the SEM morphologies of Fe-Cu alloys. It obviously suggests that all of samples exhibit typical multi-dimensional structure, of which the overall size is micron-scale and the sublevel part is nano-scale. ZVI has a feather-like shape with the length of 8–10 µm and the width of 2–3 µm, and 100Cu has a coral-like shape with the length of 2–3 µm and the width of about 1 µm. Moreover, when the Cu2+ content is no more than 25%, the obtained alloys (Fe-5Cu, Fe-10Cu and Fe-25Cu) are the feather-like structure, similar to the ZVI, indicating their main phases (Fe) control the structure. When the Cu2+ content is over 25%, the appearances of other Fe-Cu alloys change from feather-like into coral-like, implying the Cu phases gradually control their structures. In addition, the sublevel parts’ morphologies (Fig. 4 a′~f′) discover that the sublevel part of Fe phase appears like triangle pyramid and that of Cu phase like short rod, which might be associated with the phase difference between the bcc structure (Fe) and fcc structure (Cu). Combined with XRD and SEM results, the relationship between the structure and phase composition of Fe-Cu alloy could be described as follows: when the main phase is Fe, the corresponding structure is dendrite-like; when the main phase is Cu, the sublevel structures exhibit rod-like shape. Besides, the sublevel structures’ sizes of Fe-50Cu, Fe-75Cu and 100Cu increase by the order of Cu content, matching with the intensity declines of the characteristic peak of Cu(111) in XRD.

Table S3 reveals the element compositions of ZVI, Fe-Cu alloys and 100Cu. Apparently, the Cu/Fe ratios in alloys are slightly higher than those in electrolyte, because Cu2+ has stronger oxidation potential than Fe2+, which make the Cu component much more easy deposition during electrodeposition process. Moreover, owing to the inevitable oxidation in air environment, there are some oxygen elements observed in all samples. The EDS mapping results (Fe, Cu and O) of Fe-25Cu are displayed in Fig. S2a. It can be found that the distribution of Fe element is slightly richer at the trunk than the branch, indicating that the amount of Fe deposition becomes less from the inner part to outer part. In addition, a similar phenomenon is observed on the EDS analysis of Fe-10Cu (Fig. S2b), and Fe element decreases from the trunk (0.88) to the branch (0.82). This distribution characteristics of Cu and Fe elements could be explained by the difference between the standard redox potential of Fe2+/Fe° (−0.447 V) and Cu2+/Cu° (0.337 V). Owing to Cu2+ is more easily deposited than Fe2+, Fe° tends to react with free Cu2+ into Cu°, and so the Fe crystals at outer region are more difficult to grow up than those at inner region.

As the degradation experiments, Fe-Cu alloys that possess Fe components as main phase have better catalytic activity and reusability. To further identify their characteristics, XAFS was employed to study the ZVI, Fe-10Cu, Fe-25Cu and 100Cu ( Fig. 5a–c). From Fe K-edge (7112 eV) XANES spectra of ZVI, Fe-10Cu and Fe-25Cu, it can be seen that Cu heteroatoms have little effect on the basic structure of Fe phase, and only a small shift to higher energy is observed at the K-edge peaks of Fe-Cu alloys, which might be due to the mutual reaction of Cu heteroatoms and Fe lattice [37,38]. In general, the radius of Cu atom is bigger than that of Fe atom, and the electrons in the outermost shell of Cu are easy to be attracted by adjacent Fe atoms, which might influence their performance for Fenton-like reaction. The Cu K-edge XANES of 100Cu, Fe-10Cu and Fe-25Cu are presented in Fig. 5(b). The absorption K-edges of Cu in all samples is 8979 eV, signifying the chemical state is Cu°. There are two oscillation peaks of 8995 eV and 9004 eV appearing in the spectra of 100Cu, corresponding to the Cu atoms in Cu fcc lattice [39]; while the peaks of 8999 eV and 9007 eV are observed in the spectra Fe-10Cu, corresponding to the Cu atoms in Fe bcc lattice [39,40]. Furthermore, the spectra of Fe-25Cu have the characteristics of Fe-10Cu and 100Cu, and it is most possible that Fe-25Cu simultaneously possesses Cu atoms in Cu fcc and Fe bcc lattices. In addition, an edge peaks of 8982.9 eV is concomitant with the accumulation of Cu atoms [41], the intensity order of which are 100Cu > Fe-25Cu > Fe-10Cu. Because the peak of 8982.9 eV almost disappears in the spectra of Fe-10Cu, it reveals that there are no independent Cu clusters formed in Fe-10Cu, and only Cu heteroatoms are dispersed homogeneously in Fe lattice, which is consistent with the XRD analysis.

Fig. 5(c) shows that the FT EXAFS near Cu K absorption edge of Fe-10Cu, Fe-25Cu and 100Cu. The peaks of the first coordination shell of Fe-10Cu and Fe-25Cu are lower than that of 100Cu, suggesting the coordination number of the Cu atoms in Fe phase is smaller than that in Cu phase. Moreover, the coordination distances of the Cu atoms in Fe-10Cu/Fe-25Cu and 100Cu at the first shell are 2.19 Å and 2.23 Å, respectively, which signify the Cu atom is surrounded by Fe bcc lattice in Fe-10Cu/Fe-25Cu sample and that is surrounded by Cu bcc lattice in 100Cu [39]. Yet, the peak of the second coordination shell of Fe-25Cu is at 3.38 Å, close to that of 100Cu, meaning that there is a small amount of Cu atoms in Cu bcc lattice generated in Fe-25Cu. Hence, it proves again that Fe-10Cu only consists of Fe phase with Cu heteroatoms, while Fe-25Cu contains independent Cu clusters besides the Cu heteroatoms substituted in Fe phase.

We chose Fe-25Cu as typical research objects to be clearly investigated by TEM and HRTEM, as shown in Fig. 5(d) and (e). From TEM images, it is definitely gained that Fe-25Cu possesses multi-dimensional appearance, and the sizes of structure components decrease from several microns (the trunk) to dozens of nanometers (the sublevel). This appearance endows Fe-25Cu with much large specific surface area and high dispersion, which can be considered as a big advantage over the current reported Fe-Cu alloys with spherical / granular structures [24,42]. HRTEM image (Fig. 5e) displays that Fe-25Cu consists of numerous micro crystals, and according to the crystal plane striations and FFT results of different positions (Fig. 5 e1 and e2), it is much probable that the darker positions and the lighter positions are associated to Cu crystals and Fe crystals, respectively. Hence, Fe-25Cu could be considered as Fe main phases with numerous Cu heteroatoms and independent Cu clusters.

The specific surface area of Fe-Cu alloys plays an important role on their catalytic activity for providing reactive sites. Thus, we employed BET analysis to evaluate the surface area of ZVI, Fe-25Cu and 100Cu (Fig. S3). The BET area of Fe-25Cu is 29.5 m2/g, lower than ZVI (41.2 m2/g) and higher than 100Cu (12.4 m2/g), signifying that the specific surface area of Fe-Cu alloys has a declining trend when the ratio of Fe/Cu decrease. In contrast, Fe-25Cu possesses less reactive area than ZVI, but their catalytic capacities are almost same, which verify again that the Cu components (especially Cu heteroatoms) have a positive influence on the Fenton-like catalytic activity of Fe phase. Additionally, when the Cu content increases to a high degree, the Cu phase becomes the main phase of Fe-Cu alloy, causing serious downturn of catalytic activity.

Given that Fe-10Cu and Fe-25Cu exhibit better catalytic activity and reusability, it could be concluded that Fe main phases are more suitable for industrial application than Cu main phases. In particular, Fe-10Cu only possesses Fe main phases with Cu heteroatoms, while Fe-25Cu consists of Fe main phases with Cu heteroatoms and independent Cu clusters. Comparing their degradation behaviors for phenol, it could be obtained that the Cu heteroatoms in Fe phase could improve the catalytic performance, while the independent Cu clusters seem to have a negative effect on catalytic activity but a positive effect on reusability, the inner mechanisms of which would be further discussed in the below sections.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Chemical states of Fe and Cu species
ce:section.ce:para: As we known, both Fe species and Cu species could be used as Fenton-like catalysts, but the Fenton-like reactions by Fe species are far stronger than that by Cu species in this work. That is to say, the oxidation ability of Fe-Cu/H2O2 system towards organic contaminations mainly comes from that Fe2+ reacts with H2O2 into •OH [43], and so the supply of Fe2+ during the degradation experiment is the key for the catalytic behaviors of Fe-Cu alloy. Fig. 6(a) and (b) shows the Fe2p XPS results of fresh and used samples, and the corresponding chemical states distributed on samples are displayed in Table S4. Three kinds of Fe states are analyzed from Fe 2p XPS are Fe°, Fe2+ and Fe3+ at the peaks of 706.8 eV (Fe° 3/2p), 709.8 eV (Fe2+ 3/2p), 711.7 eV (Fe3+ 3/2p), 719.9 eV (Fe° 1/2p),723.1 eV (Fe2+ 1/2p), 725.1 eV (Fe3+ 1/2p) [44,45]. Normally, Fe2+ and Fe° are consider as the effective Fe species for Fenton-like reaction, while Fe3+ that is chiefly related to Fe(OH)3, Fe2O3 and FeOOH could hardly present reactive activity [46–48].

When the samples are fresh, Fe-10Cu has the maximum of low-valence Fe states (Fe° and Fe2+), matching with the optimal catalytic activity during 1st Fenton-like process. After used for 1 time, the Fe2p XPS of used ZVI only consists of Fe2+ (0.28) and Fe3+ (0.72), and Fe° state disappears completely, due to a certain amount of Fe3O4 generated on the surface of used ZVI (Fig. S4). In contrast, used Fe-10Cu and used Fe-25Cu possess an appreciable amount of Fe° and Fe2+. Especially, the ratio of Fe2+ state in used Fe-25Cu is 0.63, much higher than the other states, and therefore used Fe-25Cu could present good reusability in cycle experiments. We removed the used ZVI’s surface layer (about 10 nm) by etching treatment and analyzed the Fe2p XPS of the exposed surface, as shown in Fig. S5. It suggests that there are still a great number of low-valence Fe species (Fe° and Fe2+) on the inner of used ZVI, proving that a strong passivation layer composed of Fe3+ was formed on used ZVI to inhibit the inner active Fe species participating to the Fenton-like oxidation of phenol. As for Fe-Cu alloy, the existences of the Cu heteroatoms in Fe lattice and the independent Cu clusters could suppress the formation of passivation layer and further improve the reusability.

Cu 3/2p XPS results of fresh and used Fe-Cu alloys are presented in Fig. 6(c) and (d) and Table S5. Because of the slight surface oxidation of Fe-Cu alloys in air, the signals of Cu° of fresh samples are hardly detected by XPS, while the two characterization peaks at 932.8 eV and 933.8 eV [49] corresponding to Cu+ and Cu2+ are observed. In particular, the Cu+ state is in the majority on the surface of fresh Fe-10Cu and Fe-25Cu. After used, the amount of Cu+ state decreases evidently, while that of Cu2+ state increases, indicating that Cu+ reacts with Fe3+ or H2O2 into Cu2+, like Eqs. (5) and (6). It is proved that Cu components could assist the Fe-based Fenton-like reactions and promote the removal of phenol. Besides the peaks of Cu+ and Cu2+, the Cu 3/2p of used Fe-25Cu has a new peak at 932.2 eV (Cu° 3/2p) appearing in Fig. 6(d), suggesting the inner metal state are exposed. Given that the K sp of Cu(OH)2 in aqueous solution is 2.2 × 10−22, higher than that of Fe(OH)3 (4.0 × 10−38), this is why the Cu content of Fe-Cu alloy ran off and the inner parts are exposed after used. In other words, Cu2+ of Fe-Cu alloy has the tendency to enter the aqueous solution, which could suppress the formation of dense passivation layer on the catalyst surface. Thus, the inner active metal parts could expose continuously to promote the Fenton-like oxidation of phenol, which endow Fe-Cu alloy with better reusability than ZVI.
(5)
Cu+ + Fe3+ → Cu2+ + Fe2+
(6)
Cu+ + H2O2 → Cu2+ + •OH + OH-
(7)
Cu2+ → Cu2+ (aq·)

Fig. 7 continues to explore the resuability of Fe-25Cu by cycle experiments for 10 times. Because of the inevitable mass loss during re-collections, a minor drop of cactalytic capacity of Fe-25Cu occurred over cycle number. At each run, the degradation effecicency of phenol reached ≥ 95% within 60 min, much better than the ZVI. The XRD resluts of fresh and used Fe-25Cu after Run 10 are shown in Fig. 7(b). Compared with fresh Fe-25Cu, the peak of indepentant Cu clusters (43.4°) in used Fe-25Cu disappears, and yet the peak of Fe phase (44.5°) keeps stable, indecating that the Cu loss of Fe-25Cu during cycle experiments primarily came from the independent Cu clusters rather than the Cu heteroatoms in Fe lattice. We also studied the SEM morphology and element composition of used Fe-25Cu (Fig. 7c). After used for Run 10, Fe-25Cu still possessed the oringinal feather-like stucure, but the composition of Cu element decreased from 27.0% to 18.9%, corresponding to Cu lecaching in degradation process. The Cu leaching from the suface caused the continuous exposure of inner active parts, which make it possible for Fe-25Cu to remove phenol effictively in cycle experiments. In addition, Table S6 shows the comparisons of Fe-25Cu and other reported Fe-Cu bimetallic catalysts [19,20,26,50,51]. Owing to maintaining comparable catalytic activity and greater reusability than most of reported catalysts, Fe-25Cu could be seen as a competitive Fenton-like catalyst for practical water purification.

Fig. 8(a) demonstrations the EPR spectra of Fenton-like systems via ZVI and Fe-25Cu at 1 min and 10 min all of them have four characteristic peaks with the intensities ratios of 1: 2: 2: 1, meaning •OH is the free radical that oxidized and removed phenol during degradation experiments. At the early stage (1 min), the peaks’ intensities of •OH via ZVI and Fe-25Cu is almost equal. With the processing time rising to 10 min, the peaks’ intensities of •OH via ZVI decreased sharply, far weaker than those via Fe-25Cu, predicting Fe-25Cu has the stronger ability to generate durable •OH than ZVI, especially at the later stage, which happen to be corresponded to the degradation processes in Fig. 2. This proves again that Cu components could promote Fe-based Fenton-like process to generate more •OH.

Fig. 8(b) shows that the optimized configurations for H2O2 adsorption on the Fe atoms at the normal Fe lattice (a) and the Cu doped Fe lattice (b). The result shows that the Fe atoms at Cu doped Fe lattice have the applicable capacity for the adsorption of H2O2 molecules with the adsorption energy (A.E.) of −0.46 eV, lower than those on the normal Fe lattice (A.E.= −0.34 eV), which indicate that the Cu heteroatoms could enable the adjacent Fe atoms to attract more H2O2 for generating •OH. On the contrary, the absorption energy of Cu heteroatoms for H2O2 is only −0.09 eV, far higher than that of Fe atoms, verifying that the Fe-based Fenton-like oxidation dominates the whole catalytic degradation process.

Meanwhile, the metal ions during degradation experiments via Fe-25Cu were detected by ICP, as shown in Fig. S6. Apparently, Cu leaching is much higher than Fe leaching, corresponding to the Cu dissolution from used Fe-25Cu. When the degradation time is 60 min, the system obtains about 0.4 ppm Fe ions and 3.0 ppm Cu ions. For exploring the effect of homogeneous metal ions, the degradation experiment via 0.4 ppm Fe2+ + 3.0 ppm Cu2+ was carried out, and shown in Fig. S7. It could be seen that the kinetics constant of homogeneous reaction is only 0.0389, far lower than that of Fe-25Cu. Moreover, we utilized KI (capturing •OH on catalyst’s surface) and N-butanol (capturing •OH on catalyst’s surface and in aqueous solution) as radical scavengers to study the effects of different scavengers on the degradation behavior of Fe-25Cu, respectively. The result (Fig. S8) discloses that both KI and N-butanol could suppress the catalytic activity of Fe-25Cu substantially, revealing that the homogenous metal ions have relatively smaller effects on the whole degradation process, and the degradation ability of Fe-25Cu mainly come from on the •OH generated on heterogeneous surface.

Fig. 9 performs C1s XPS results of used catalysts, and there are four peaks of sp2C at 284.6 eV, C–O at 286.7 eV, CO at 287.8 eV and COO at 288.8 eV. Among them, the peaks of C–O, CO and COO are associated with organic contaminations, which might come from typical degradation intermediate products including benzoquinone, maleic and oxalic acids [52,53]. Accordingly, we calculated the number of organic contaminations based on the total ratios of C–O, CO and COO (Table S7). It could be seen that used ZVI possesses lots of organic contaminations (0.51), much more than used Fe-10Cu (0.13) and used Fe-25Cu (0.14), which might be one of important factors that reduces the catalytic activity of used ZVI. Since the Cu2+ dissolution could disturb the contaminations deposition, the number of organic contaminations on Fe-Cu alloys decreases sharply. This proves that the Cu2+ dissolution could suppress the surface passivation of Fe-Cu alloys and enable them to exhibit better reusability than ZVI. Besides, the independent Cu clusters are easier to be dissolved than the Cu heteroatoms throughout degradation process, and this is why Fe-25Cu has stronger reusability than Fe-10Cu in cycle experiments.

From the above results, we proposed the possible Fenton-like mechanisms of Fe-Cu alloy with taking Fe-25Cu as an example, as displayed in Fig. 10. Fe-based Fenton-like oxidation dominates the degradation process, while the Cu species play an assistant role. Firstly, the Cu components (Cu° or Cu+) could accelerate the transformation of Fe3+ / Fe2+ through Eq. (4)
, and then the re-generated Fe2+ further activate more H2O2 into •OH for phenol degradation (Fig. 10a). Based on the different existing state, the Cu heteroatoms in Fe lattice and the independent Cu clusters present different functions on the behavior of degradation processes: ① The Cu heteroatoms could promote the adsorption of H2O2 on the adjacent Fe atoms and activate more H2O2 into •OH for the degradation processes; ② The independent Cu clusters could be dissolved in aqueous solution progressively owing to the reactions of Eqs. (5)–(7) and therefore suppress the formation of the surface passivation layer, which effectively raise the reusability of Fe-25Cu, as shown in Fig. 10(b).

In conclusion, we prepared the hierarchical Fe-Cu alloy as Fenton-like catalyst by facile electrodeposition process and tested the catalytic activity with phenol degradation. Owing to the close atomic radius and reduction potential, the Cu and Fe atoms are easy to be co-deposited as solid solutions that include one element as heteroatoms and the other as main phase. Fe-25Cu obtained in this study possesses the optimal application prospect because of removing ≥ 99% phenol within 30 min and being reused sustainably for 10 times. In particular, Fe-based Fenton-like reactions dominate the degradation process, and the Cu components including Cu heteroatoms and independent Cu clusters play an assistant role. Besides promoting the transformation of Fe3+/Fe2+, the Cu heteroatoms can enhance the H2O2 adsorption for improving the catalytic activity, and the independent Cu clusters can suppress the passivation layer formation for boosting the reusability. This approach offers a general and valuable insight to design alloy catalysts for industrial application and optimize the catalytic performance based on the various co-existence states, and additionally more attention should be focused to reduce the metal ions dissolving for practical water purification.

Qixing Xia: Conceptualization, Methodology, Investigation, Writing – original draft, Writing – review & editing, Funding acquisition. Dongjia Zhang: Conceptualization, Methodology, Investigation, Funding acquisition. Zhongping Yao: Conceptualization, Writing – review & editing, Supervision, Funding acquisition. Zhaohua Jiang: Writing – review & editing, Supervision.
